head.title: Topics of The Times; Ice Follies

hedline.hl1: Topics of The Times; Ice Follies

block.p: We're havin' a heat wave, a tropical heat wave. The temperature has finally climbed out of the single digits. The news programs have scrubbed their spots on the return of the Ice Age.
For this we should heave a warm sigh. Instead, we find ourselves with a head full of Andy Rooneyesque whiny questions. To wit:
We're havin' a heat wave, a tropical heat wave. The temperature has finally climbed out of the single digits. The news programs have scrubbed their spots on the return of the Ice Age.
For this we should heave a warm sigh. Instead, we find ourselves with a head full of Andy Rooneyesque whiny questions. To wit:

1. How does The Old Farmer's Almanac account for the fact that it predicted a "warmer than normal" January in New York? Software glitch? Is a special prosecutor of fearsome probity -- with subpoena powers -- in order here?
2. Why do local television reporters insist on delivering live, outdoor reports from Fort Lee, N.J., in subzero temperatures? Do they get paid extra for shivering on-camera?
3. Just what did happen to global warming? And where is the greenhouse effect when you need it?

4. Who was the guy with the hockey stick the other night -- when the temperature was exactly zero -- skating on an ice-slicked handball court at 35th Street and Second Avenue, shooting hockey pucks against the backboard?
5. If he had been alive in New York City last week, could Robert Frost have written: "Some say the world will end in fire/ Some say the world will end in ice"? Who could have voted for fire?
6. Is it possible that the people who deliver pizza and Chinese food in snow, ice and other aggressive forms of weather could be persuaded to take over the U.S. Postal Service?
7. From a purely psychological standpoint, does knowing that the wind-chill factor is minus 26, or minus 37, make any difference at all?
